title: Jim Purvis
text:
Jim Purvis was a Scottish former <a href="Association%20football">football</a> <a href="inside%20forward">inside forward</a> who played professionally in the <a href="American%20Soccer%20League%20%281921-1933%29">American Soccer League</a>.
Purvis played for several youth teams, but never played professionally in Scotland before moving the United States and settling in <a href="Philadelphia%2C%20Pennsylvania">Philadelphia, Pennsylvania</a>. In 1922, he joined <a href="Fleisher%20Yarn">Fleisher Yarn</a> which played in the Allied Amateur League of Philadelphia. Fleisher moved up to the <a href="American%20Soccer%20League%20%281921-1933%29">American Soccer League</a> in 1924 and Purvis scored seventeen goals in thirty-five league games and another two goals in two league cup games. On July 29, 1925, Purvis signed with <a href="Bethlehem%20Steel%20F.C.%20%281907%E2%80%9330%29">Bethlehem Steel</a>. Purvis scored twenty-one goals in twenty-two games before suffering a season ending ankle injury in April 1926. Bethlehem sent him to <a href="Indiana%20Flooring">Indiana Flooring</a> at the end of the season. He played one season with Indiana before moving to the <a href="New%20York%20Nationals%20%28ASL%29">New York Nationals</a> for the 1927-1928 season. He moved again, beginning the 1928-1929 season with <a href="Philadelphia%20Field%20Club%23Philadelphia%20F.C.%20III">Philadelphia F.C.</a> and finishing it with the <a href="Brooklyn%20Wanderers">Brooklyn Wanderers</a>. He moved to the <a href="Bridgeport%20Bears">Bridgeport Bears</a> in the fall of 1929, but when the team experienced significant financial difficulties with the onset of the <a href="Great%20Depression">Great Depression</a>, the team merged with Philadelphia where Purvis finished his professional career.
In August 1935, <a href="Philadelphia%20United%20German-Hungarians">Philadelphia United German-Hungarians</a> hired Purvis to manage the team.
